Installing from packages on Alpine Linux
Alpine Linux provides PHP packages in its community repository. These packages can be installed using the apk package manager. Alpine Linux is commonly used in container environments due to its small footprint.
&warn.install.third-party-support;
Installing packages
PHP packages in Alpine Linux are versioned (e.g. php83 for PHP 8.3). The available version depends on the Alpine release being used.
Before installing a package, ensure the package index is up to date by running apk update.
Alpine Install Example
# apk add php83 php83-common
Alpine does not automatically configure PHP for a web server. The web server and PHP-FPM need to be configured and started separately. For example:
Enabling and starting PHP-FPM
# apk add php83-fpm # rc-update add php-fpm83 default # rc-service php-fpm83 start
Installing additional extensions
Only the core modules are installed with the base package. Additional extensions such as
MySQL cURL GD etc.
can be installed as separate packages.
Searching for available PHP packages
# apk search php83
The list of packages includes the CLI, FPM, and many extensions. When extensions are installed, their dependencies are automatically resolved.
Install PHP with MySQL, GD
# apk add php83-mysqli php83-gd
Extension configuration files are placed in /etc/php83/conf.d/. After installing new extensions, PHP-FPM (or the web server) needs to be restarted for the changes to take effect.
